about.description:
This package is a generic way to obtain the C compiler for your system
that conda-forge used to compile its ecosystem.  This compiler is,
therefore, guaranteed to be ABI compatible with the conda packages
you have installed.

This compiler metapackage is a convenience ONLY for users.
Do NOT use this package as a build or host dependency in other
recipes.  Use the Jinja template function compiler('c') instead.
about.summary: A metapackage to obtain a C compiler

name: c-compiler
raw_recipe:
# This file created by conda-build 3.20.4
# ------------------------------------------------

package:
    name: c-compiler
    version: 1.1.1
build:
    noarch: false
    number: '1'
    script: build-symlinks.sh
    string: hc970988_1
requirements:
    host:
        - _libgcc_mutex 0.1 conda_forge
        - _openmp_mutex 4.5 1_gnu
        - binutils 2.35 hb79408c_9
        - binutils_impl_linux-ppc64le 2.35 h9026189_9
        - binutils_linux-ppc64le 2.35 hd8189f2_29
        - gcc_impl_linux-ppc64le 9.3.0 h8de11e6_17
        - gcc_linux-ppc64le 9.3.0 h1b213c7_29
        - kernel-headers_linux-ppc64le 3.10.0 hbe0c576_10
        - ld_impl_linux-ppc64le 2.35 h78afe3c_9
        - libgcc-devel_linux-ppc64le 9.3.0 h206f0cf_17
        - libgcc-ng 9.3.0 hb998004_17
        - libgomp 9.3.0 hb998004_17
        - libstdcxx-ng 9.3.0 h42fc837_17
        - sysroot_linux-ppc64le 2.17 h8b29623_10
    run:
        - binutils
        - gcc_linux-ppc64le 9.*
        - libgcc-ng >=9.3.0
test:
    commands:
        - $CC --help
        - cc --help > /dev/null
        - echo "Checking cc resolves to a path containing ${BUILD}"
        - readlink $(which cc) | grep -q "${BUILD}"
        - cpp --help > /dev/null
        - echo "Checking cpp resolves to a path containing ${BUILD}"
        - readlink $(which cpp) | grep -q "${BUILD}"
        - gcc --help > /dev/null
        - echo "Checking gcc resolves to a path containing ${BUILD}"
        - readlink $(which gcc) | grep -q "${BUILD}"
        - gcc-ar --help > /dev/null
        - echo "Checking gcc-ar resolves to a path containing ${BUILD}"
        - readlink $(which gcc-ar) | grep -q "${BUILD}"
        - gcc-nm --help > /dev/null
        - echo "Checking gcc-nm resolves to a path containing ${BUILD}"
        - readlink $(which gcc-nm) | grep -q "${BUILD}"
        - gcc-ranlib --help > /dev/null
        - echo "Checking gcc-ranlib resolves to a path containing ${BUILD}"
        - readlink $(which gcc-ranlib) | grep -q "${BUILD}"
        - gcov --help > /dev/null
        - echo "Checking gcov resolves to a path containing ${BUILD}"
        - readlink $(which gcov) | grep -q "${BUILD}"
        - gcov-dump --help > /dev/null
        - echo "Checking gcov-dump resolves to a path containing ${BUILD}"
        - readlink $(which gcov-dump) | grep -q "${BUILD}"
        - gcov-tool --help > /dev/null
        - echo "Checking gcov-tool resolves to a path containing ${BUILD}"
        - readlink $(which gcov-tool) | grep -q "${BUILD}"
about:
    description: 'This package is a generic way to obtain the C compiler for your
        system

        that conda-forge used to compile its ecosystem.  This compiler is,

        therefore, guaranteed to be ABI compatible with the conda packages

        you have installed.


        This compiler metapackage is a convenience ONLY for users.

        Do NOT use this package as a build or host dependency in other

        recipes.  Use the Jinja template function compiler(''c'') instead.

        '
    home: https://conda-forge.org
    license: BSD
    summary: A metapackage to obtain a C compiler
extra:
    copy_test_source_files: true
    final: true
    recipe-maintainers:
        - chrisburr
        - duncanmmacleod
        - isuruf
        - scopatz
